App description:
Explore our Solar System, view constellations and meteor showers in your night sky, stand in the footsteps of Neil Armstrong & Buzz Aldrin on the Moon, explore Mars with the Curiosity Rover, and hold planets, moons, asteroids and even stars in palm of your hand.

Explore the solar system, from the Sun to the moons of Saturn and out to the farthest reaches of Pluto. Gaze down and marvel at our solar system from above. Look up in wonder at the rings of Uranus. Feel the awe of floating in space around worlds no human has yet set foot on. See how the constellations of our night sky are made up of stars distant to each other in both space and time. Embrace the impossible distances and the inordinate scale of our universe.

Star Chart currently includes:
- An accurate real-time simulation of the night sky.
- A 3D solar system to explore.
- Orrery tour and exploration 
- Moments in Time: set foot on the Moon and Mars, explore the ISS Cupola & visit the New Horizons probe.

Requested Permissions:


Depending on your device and OS version, our apps may request you to approve certain permissions. Below is a list of these permissions and info on why our apps - eg Star Chart - ask for these permissions.


Location data:


Star Chart needs access to your device's location data (GPS data) tocalculate a visual representation of the night sky. Wedetermine where on Earth you are located and therefore what night sky objects are visible to you from your current location. Denying access to location data means that you will not get an accurate reading of the night sky unless you manually set your location data in some other way. To calculate a visual representation of the night sky / celestial objects based on your current location we require access to some form of GPS data. If none is provided, the representation of the night sky will be incorrect.


Internet access:
On some OS versions, Star Chart asks for permission to use the Internet so that it can, amongst other things:
Download updated information on the solar system, satellite and night sky bodies, including trajectories and general data.
Connect to servers for access to purchasing and downloading in-app upgrades.
Connect to our support page.
Send a support email.
Link to your own or our Social Media sites.
Access net-based APIs (egVoice Controls).


Record Audio:


On some platforms, Star Chart allows English speaking users to control Star Chart with Voice Commands. These voice commands areinterpretedby the OS's Voice API. On Android, using the Voice API for voice commands requires us to ask all users in all territories to give permission for Star Chart to 'Record Audio'.


We do not collect any audio from your device unless you specifically trigger the voice command function, and we do not share that data with anyone else other than as required by the API to interpret the audio commands. For example, some voice command software sends audio command snippets to a server where they are analysed & interpretedbefore the results are returned to the app so that your commands can be actioned. If you want to look at a planet (even Pluto even though it shouldnt be there) there is a dedicated submenu to get you over to it and subsequently you can find moons that way but despite searching for 20 or so minutes I couldnt find a way to do this with dwarf planets and asteroids. I was able to look at Ceres and Eros but only because I could work out where they were approximately and then spent a while pixel hunting. There are a lot of awesome things in our solar system outside of planets and moons and it should be easier to find them.

I also couldnt find any artificial satellites that you could view either. One of my favourite things to do in Solar Walker is follow along with the stuff weve launched. If you could see where stuff like the Tesla or Voyager probes were currently that would be great and even better would be a mode that follows their journey through the system. Also having a toggle to view artificial satellites around planet systems would be interesting even if you couldnt zoom in for a full 3D model (Im aware that suggesting modelling even a few dozen significant satellites that we have put up would be quite expensive to do model wise).

I did the tutorials for all modes and kept having to remember that the trip button was back and would take me back to the main menu. Perhaps to leave to the main menu requires holding it down for a few seconds might alleviate some of accidental returns to the main menu.

Once again veering into expensive territory but Id appreciate a bit more information on something when you go into a close up view. The information that is there is nice (oh though I didnt see indication of gravity levels on it) but a summary paragraph saying why this thing is cool could go a long way. Now Ive mainly mentioned issues with the app so far but it is just such a kick flying around a giant solar system.
